li.p: Draw graphs of three different antiderivatives of the function g(x) = x^2. How are these graphs related?
In Activity you found one antiderivative of k(x) = \frac{1}{x^2}. What is the general antiderivative of k?
In Activity you found one antiderivative of r(x) = \frac{1}{x} for x\gt 0. Verify that for x \lt 0, the function \ln(-x) is an antiderivative of r. What is the general antiderivative of r?

Why can't we use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to compute \int_{-1}^{1} \frac{1}{x^2}\,dx? What answer would we get if we tried to compute this integral with the FTC, using the general antiderivative from part (d)?
What does adding a constant to a function do to its graph?
Treat the two pieces separately.
There are still two pieces.
Notice that there are two pieces!
Again there are two pieces, now with two different antiderivative formulas.
Look at the hypotheses of the FTC.
They are each shifted up or down by a constant distance.
No; the function is not continuous on [-1,1].
They are each shifted up or down by a constant distance.

There are again two pieces, even though they are only separated by a single missing point. Thus both can be shifted independently, and the general antiderivative is
H(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + C_1, \amp \ \text{if}\ x \lt -1 \\ 2x + C_2, \amp \ \text{if}\ x \gt -1. \end{cases}

Again there are two pieces, though now separated by an asymptote rather than a hole. Thus both can be shifted independently, and the general antiderivative is
K(x) = \begin{cases} -\frac{1}{x} + C_1, \amp \ \text{if}\ x \lt 0 \\ -\frac{1}{x} + C_2, \amp \ \text{if}\ x \gt 0. \end{cases}

Still two pieces, although the formulas for the antiderivative is now different on the two pieces. The general antiderivative is
R(x) = \begin{cases} \ln(-x) + C_1, \amp \ \text{if}\ x \lt 0 \\ \ln(x) + C_2, \amp \ \text{if}\ x \gt 0. \end{cases}

The FTC requires as one of its hypotheses that the function being integrated be continuous on the entire interval [a,b]. This is not the case here: \frac{1}{x^2} is not continuous at x=0. Thus, the FTC does not apply.
Note that if we didn't notice this and tried to apply the FTC with the general antiderivative given in part (d), as our answer we would get C_2 - C_1 - 2: the constants don't cancel.
